misconceptions.name: Misinterpreting the problem requirements (wrong program written)
misconceptions.description: The student implemented a road trip cost calculator instead of a number guessing game. They did not include any random number generation, guessing loop, or 'Too high/Too low' feedback, indicating they did not translate or follow the given specification for the number guessing game.
misconceptions.student_belief: I should write a program that reads driving distance, miles per gallon, and price per gallon, then computes and prints the cost of driving.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The program should implement a number guessing game where the computer chooses a random integer between 1 and 100, then repeatedly prompts the user to guess until they are correct, giving 'Too high' or 'Too low' hints and reporting how many guesses were taken.
symptoms: Program reads distance, mpg, and price instead of a guessed number.
No use of Random or generation of a secret number between 1 and 100.
No loop to allow multiple guesses.
No conditional logic that prints 'Too high' or 'Too low'.
Final output is a cost of driving, not a success message with number of guesses.
misconceptions.root_cause: Failure to correctly interpret or follow the problem description; the student seems to have implemented a different textbook-style problem (road trip cost) instead of the requested number guessing game.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Re-read the problem statement carefully and identify the required inputs, processing, and outputs. Start by generating a random number (1–100) using Random, then design a loop that repeatedly prompts for guesses, compares each guess to the secret number, prints 'Too high' or 'Too low' as needed, and stops when the correct guess is entered.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: The entire program focuses on computing driving cost and contains none of the required elements of a number guessing game, strongly indicating the student implemented the wrong problem.

evidence.note: All input and output are about driving distance, fuel efficiency, and fuel price; there is no random number, guessing, or hint logic for a number guessing game.

misconceptions.name: Misinterpreting Problem Requirements
misconceptions.description: The student implemented a complete solution for an unrelated problem (Road Trip Cost calculation) instead of the required 'Number Guessing Game' for Q2. Consequently, all elements required by the Q2 rubric are missing.
misconceptions.student_belief: The submitted code (RoadTripCost) fulfills the requirements for Q2, or the wrong file was submitted.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: Q2 requires a program that generates a random number (1-100), takes user guesses in a loop, and provides conditional feedback ('Too high' / 'Too low').
symptoms: Code calculates fuel cost based on inputs (distance, mpg, price)
Absence of required 'Random' class usage
Absence of loop structure for repeated guesses
Absence of conditional logic to compare guess vs. answer
misconceptions.root_cause: The student submitted code for an entirely different assignment/problem, demonstrating a critical failure to meet the requirements of Q2.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Review the instructions for Question 2 and ensure the submitted code implements the correct logic for the Number Guessing Game.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: The code's variable names, input prompts, and calculation clearly indicate a 'Road Trip Cost' program, which is completely irrelevant to the assigned Number Guessing Game.

evidence.note: The entire program implements a calculation routine completely unrelated to the required game structure.

misconceptions.name: Wrong Problem Solved
misconceptions.description: Student solved a completely different problem (Road Trip Cost Calculator) instead of the Number Guessing Game specified in Q2.
misconceptions.student_belief: The student appears to believe they are solving a road trip cost calculation problem, not implementing a number guessing game.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The assignment requires implementing a Number Guessing Game where: (1) the computer generates a random number between 1-100, (2) the user makes repeated guesses, (3) the program provides 'Too high' or 'Too low' feedback, and (4) the program counts and displays the number of guesses when correct.
symptoms: Code reads three numeric inputs (distance, mpg, price) instead of guessing game inputs
Code performs arithmetic calculation (distance/mpg)*price instead of random number generation
No Random class or random number generation present
No loop for multiple guesses
No conditional logic for 'Too high'/'Too low' comparisons
Program terminates after single calculation instead of looping until correct guess
misconceptions.root_cause: Student either misread the assignment, submitted code from a different problem, or confused the requirements with a previous assignment.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Read the Q2 requirements carefully. The program must: (1) Use Random class to generate answer between 1-100, (2) Loop asking for guesses, (3) Compare each guess to the answer and print 'Too high' or 'Too low', (4) Exit loop when guess equals answer and print total guess count.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: Extremely high confidence because the submitted code solves an entirely different problem. There is zero overlap with the Number Guessing Game requirements. The code reads three inputs and performs a single calculation, whereas Q2 requires random number generation, looping, and comparison logic.

evidence.note: Student implemented a road trip cost calculator with three inputs and a single arithmetic calculation, which has no relation to the Number Guessing Game requirements.
Class name 'RoadTripCost' and single import (Scanner only) indicates student did not implement guessing game logic which requires java.util.Random.

misconceptions.name: Implemented a different problem than the specified number guessing game
misconceptions.description: The student wrote a program to calculate the cost of a road trip using distance, miles per gallon, and fuel price instead of implementing the required number guessing game where the computer picks a random number between 1 and 100 and the user keeps guessing until correct with "Too high"/"Too low" hints.
misconceptions.student_belief: I should write a program that reads driving distance, miles per gallon, and fuel price from the user and outputs the cost of driving.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The task is to write a number guessing game: the computer generates a random integer between 1 and 100, the user repeatedly guesses until they get the correct number, and after each incorrect guess the program prints whether the guess was "Too high" or "Too low" before eventually reporting the number of guesses.
symptoms: Program prompts for driving distance, miles per gallon, and price per gallon instead of guesses.
No use of Random or any random-number generation.
No loop that allows repeated guesses.
No conditional logic comparing a guess to a secret number (no "Too high"/"Too low" messages).
Program terminates after computing and printing a single arithmetic expression unrelated to guessing.
misconceptions.root_cause: Misinterpretation of the problem requirements; the student appears to have implemented a different textbook-style exercise (trip cost calculator) instead of the specified number guessing game.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Re-read the problem statement carefully and list the required features (random number generation between 1 and 100, repeated guesses in a loop, feedback "Too high"/"Too low", and termination only when the guess is correct). Then design your program structure (variables, Random object, loop, conditionals) around those requirements rather than another exercise.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: Every part of the submitted code addresses a road-trip cost calculation and none of it relates to a guessing game, random numbers, or comparative feedback, which strongly indicates the problem was misunderstood.

evidence.note: All input and calculations focus on driving distance, fuel efficiency, and fuel price, with no random number, guesses, or feedback messages as required by the number guessing game specification.

misconceptions.name: Misinterpretation of Assignment Requirements
misconceptions.description: The student submitted a solution for a different problem (Road Trip Cost Calculator) instead of the requested Number Guessing Game.
misconceptions.student_belief: The student appears to have submitted code for the wrong assignment or misunderstood the primary objective of Q2, neglecting all specific requirements for a guessing game (random number generation, iterative guessing loop, and conditional feedback logic).
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The task required implementing a specific structure: initializing a random number, using a loop to accept continuous user input, and providing 'Too high'/'Too low' feedback until terminated by a correct guess.
symptoms: The submitted code calculates road trip cost instead of implementing a guessing game.
Crucial components like random number generation, iterative loops, and conditional logic specific to the hint system are missing.
misconceptions.root_cause: Failure to read or adhere to the assigned question (Q2).
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Ensure the submitted code directly addresses the stated problem description and required features (random number, loop, high/low comparison). Review the requirements for Q2, the Number Guessing Game.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: The submitted code is entirely unrelated to the assignment prompt's requirements, demonstrating a complete misunderstanding or selection of the wrong file.

evidence.note: The entire program implements a cost calculation, showing no attempt to solve the Number Guessing Game.

misconceptions.name: Misinterpreted Problem Requirements
misconceptions.description: Student submitted a solution to a completely different problem (road trip cost calculator) instead of implementing the required Number Guessing Game.
misconceptions.student_belief: The student appears to have either answered the wrong question or attempted a different assignment entirely.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The assignment requires implementing a number guessing game where: (1) computer picks random number 1-100, (2) user guesses repeatedly, (3) program provides 'Too high'/'Too low' feedback, (4) game ends when guess is correct with guess count displayed.
symptoms: Program reads three numeric inputs instead of one guess at a time
Program calculates a cost formula instead of comparing guess to secret number
No random number generation
No looping structure for multiple guesses
No conditional feedback about guess correctness
misconceptions.root_cause: Complete misunderstanding of the assignment requirements - student either read the wrong question or attempted to answer a different problem.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Re-read the Q2 assignment carefully. Start fresh by: (1) Importing Random class, (2) Creating random number 1-100, (3) Using a while loop with user input for guesses, (4) Adding if-statements to compare guess vs answer, (5) Adding a counter and printing final result.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: Absolute certainty - the submitted code implements a completely different algorithm with different inputs, logic, and output than the assignment specification.

evidence.note: Code implements a road trip cost calculator, not a guessing game. Wrong problem entirely.
Class name is 'RoadTripCost' which indicates student solved a different problem, not the Number Guessing Game.
